Description: Egyptian terracotta figure of Sothic dog. Front right paw and part of base missing. Mould-made and hollow. White coating traces on dog, with possibly brown or black paint. Dark red-brown Nile silt fabric with abundant fine gold mica, quartz and white inclusions.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Classical Archaeology, Cambridge. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Probably locally produced at the Naukratis Terracottas workshop that was operational in the 3rd to 2nd century BC and possibly later. Representation of Sirios, the Sothic dog, or Dog Star Sirius, associated with Isis. Sothic dog on bench is a common subject, with similar examples from Egypt dating to the Ptolemaic period (Besques 1992, pl.80 D/E no.4541; Bayer-Niemeier 1988, pl.109.7, no.626). However Bailey argues these are a 1st to 2nd century AD phenomenon (Bailey 2008, nos 3704-15). Bayer Niemeier, E. 1988. Liebieghaus Museum Alter Plastik. Bildwerke der Sammlung Kaufmann, 1.
